results.title: Rice Farming [B&W]
results.creator_credit: Jean Halliday, Lex Halliday and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description: Classroom film on the Australian rice industry: rice growing in Murrumbidgee irrigation area; preparation of the fields; mechanised sowing in the spring; subsequent flooding of paddy fields until harvesting seven months later; harvesting the crop yielding fifty bags to the acre; complementary crops grown on rice farms during winter; milling processes including sifting, removing full, polishing and bagging at local mills. Half the annual rice crop satisfies the home market; the remainder is exported principally in unpolished form.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jean Halliday, Lex Halliday and Australian Instructional Films

results.title: Rice
results.creator_credit: Wheaton Galentine, Willard Van Dyke and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description: Discusses the importance of rice in the life and culture of the people of Asia, pointing out that primitive methods cannot produce enough food for Asia’s rapidly increasing population. Describes the work of two American foundations which have established a research and training centre to assist Asian farmers increase their yield. Written by Howard Enders Narrated by John Connell.

results.title: Rhodesia and Nyasaland today
results.creator_credit: Gordon Bradley, Associated Television and Rank Organisation Film Productions
results.brief_description: Surveys the progress and problems of Rhodesia and Nyasaland; the African quarter of Harari; tobacco plantations; Government farming schemes; industrial training; Victoria Falls; Kariba power station; Nyasaland’s tea production. Transition of Africans from their way of life to the European pattern.

results.title: Reverie de Claude Debussy
results.creator_credit: Jean Mitry, Anatole Dauman, R. Lifchitz and Argos Films
results.brief_description: A visual interpretation of four piano works by Claude Debussy; “Mouvements”, “Cloches a Travers Les Feuilles”, “Reverie” and “Clair de Lune”. A montage of static forest shots and idyllic woodlands.

results.title: Return to Florence
results.brief_description: When Florence flooded in 1966 the oily waters did terrible damage to the art treasures. This program shows the experts from many countries who, under the guidance of UNESCO, continue the slow, painstaking process of restoration. Research and commentary by Rex Keating. Music by Muir Mathieson.

results.title: Respect for property
results.brief_description: A gang of boys break into a rival group’s club house and destroy much of the contents. Instead of seeking revenge, the boys who suffered the damage seek the help of a local policeman who explains to them the meaning of private and public property. They relate their own loss to the damage they have done on school property and realise that public property is owned by everyone and not just one individual.

results.title: Reproduction among mammals
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and ERPI Classroom Films
results.brief_description: Direct photography, animation, micro-cinematography and three-dimensional animation are used to tell the story of embryology. The pig - familiar domestic animal - is selected to illustrate the process of generation. The story is fundamentally complete from the formation of the original male and female germ cells, to the active newborn pig, including such processes as fertilization, cleavage, blastulation, formation of neural folds, development of membranes and embryonic circulation and parturition.

results.title: Report for Colombo
results.brief_description: A report on the Colombo Plan, showing the services and facilities it is offering to the countries of south-east Asia. Shows visits of Indian, Pakistani and Ceylonese students and scientists to Australia; Asian students studying in Australian schools, technical colleges and universities; shipment of food, materials and equipment to south-east Asia.
